Dorfromantik is a delightful gem of a game that has truly captured my heart. If you're seeking a relaxing and visually stunning experience, look no further because this game is an absolute masterpiece.

First and foremost, the artwork and design in Dorfromantik are simply breathtaking. The hand-drawn landscapes are so charming and picturesque that you'll often find yourself just gazing at the scenery. The attention to detail and the vibrant, calming colors create a tranquil atmosphere that's perfect for unwinding.

The gameplay is easy to grasp, yet it offers a surprising depth of strategy. The concept of placing hexagonal tiles to build a pastoral landscape is both intuitive and creative. You'll quickly find yourself engrossed in the challenge of creating the most beautiful and harmonious world possible. The game strikes a perfect balance between being relaxing and engaging, making it suitable for both casual players and those who enjoy more in-depth, thought-provoking experiences.

The relaxing soundtrack complements the gameplay beautifully. It enhances the tranquil ambiance and is just a joy to listen to while you immerse yourself in the world of Dorfromantik. It's a game that encourages you to slow down, take your time, and appreciate the simple pleasures of life.

One of the most appealing aspects of Dorfromantik is its endless mode. There's no rush or time pressure, and you can play at your own pace, creating your dream landscape without limitations. This design choice allows for a highly personalized and meditative experience, making it the perfect game to unwind with after a long day.

Dorfromantik's replayability is impressive as well. Each new game offers a fresh opportunity to experiment with different tile placements, develop new strategies, and improve your high score. It's a game that you can return to time and time again without it ever feeling repetitive.

In a world filled with fast-paced, high-stress games, Dorfromantik is a breath of fresh air. It's a peaceful, engaging, and visually stunning experience that will soothe your soul and provide hours of enjoyment. If you're looking for a game that helps you relax and appreciate the simple beauty of creating your own idyllic world, Dorfromantik is a must-play. It's a true work of art in the gaming world, and I can't recommend it enough!

149643299.review:
I had Dorfromantik on my Wishlist for some time, always waiting for a sale greater than 20%. The overwhelmingly positive reviews intrigued me, but I was not moved to purchase. One day a streamer on Twitch was playing it, but I didn't recognize it at first. "Wow this game looks great! This is right up my alley! What's the name?" "Dorfromantik". 

From that moment I've been hooked. I downloaded it that day, and have already sunk over 8 hours into it over the weekend. Even my partner loves it, and she never games. There is something so rewarding about placing the tiles - especially when they match up perfectly - getting points, and watching your beautiful map grow bigger and better, that hits all the right spots. Hidden behind the very simple mechanics and beautiful design is an incredible depth and loads of strategy. Sure you can have an amazing time tinkering around and creating a cute little countryside, but you can also spend minutes agonizing over each tile placement and thinking ahead to reach those high scores.

Between this depth of play, the ease to enter and exit a game, and the gorgeous graphics and sounds, you'll be hooked just like I was. Fans of the board game Carcassone will feel at home, and to a lesser extent Settlers of Catan or Ticket to Ride. Even if you don't game, and ignore the quests and points, just making a really cool map with all the beautiful and varied tiles is bound to bring enjoyment.

Dorfromantik will undoubtedly be at the top of my favourite games list for some time, which is crazy to think that I had slept on it so long. I encourage you to give it a go!

For the Devs: Possible future improvements - not that they're really needed - but perhaps a new tile or two that can be unlocked and are ultra rare could be a great addition to the ones already available! Also, perhaps a 'power up' system could be interesting, where you can bring in certain powers to a game (for example, the ability to 'hold' a piece until later, or randomize one, or to undo two tiles instead of just one, or the ability to ignore the first loss of the round). These could help players really play to their playstyle and add an extra element of control to games.

147888810.review:
A nice puzzle game to play every now-and then. 

The store page explains it quite well. You try to place down randomly-generated hexagonal tiles so that their borders match neighbouring tiles. For example a tile might have trees on three sides, houses on one side, and farm fields on two, and you'd want to place it so that the edges with trees are placed against the side of another placed tile that also has trees, while the side with houses is against the side of another tile with houses, etc.

Railways and rivers are a bit different as they have to be connected so that one railway track/river goes into another without ending at the edge of a tile.

You only have a limited number of tiles, but you can get more with "quests". A quest can be generated by a tile when you place it, or by special tiles that appear on the map, with the quest activating when you reach the tile. A quest is visible as a little speech bubble above a tile with a number indicating that you will be rewarded with more tiles if you connect that number of a specific feature to that tile. For example, it might say to connect 20 houses to that tile. Most tiles have multiple houses on them, so you won't need to connect 20 tiles with houses, but the connection needs to be continuous, with no other features like fields or water separating some houses from others, even on single tiles. It is the same with trees, water, etc.

You earn points every time the side of one tile is matched with a side of another with the same feature. You also earn an extra tile every time you get a perfect placement (a tile with all its sides matching the features on neighbouring tiles). Once you run out of tiles it's game over and you get your score.

Some things I would've liked to see are some sort of campaign and/or scenarios with unique challenges to keep things interesting, as the game is a little bare-bones, but the concept is good enough that it is still okay without. There are at least a few different modes to play around with: 
- classic (normal gameplay)
- quick play (awards fewer tiles so games don't last as long)
- hard mode (tiles have more difficult/varied feature combinations)
- creative mode (unlimited tiles and can place any you want)
- custom mode (allows you to specify some parameters like how often features appear on tiles, add a time limit, etc)
- monthly challenge (everyone is provided with an identical seed and a limited area to place tiles, you can look at leaderboards to see how your results compare to others)


Overall it is a recommend from me. Price is a little steep for a simple puzzle game but not too bad.
6/10

146770695.review:
This game is beautiful and the gameplay gets off to a strong start. Although my first game went well (I placed 780 tiles with a score of 42k) it also revealed to me that there are some serious flaws with this game's design. In particular, I would highlight four principal design failures:

1. As the size of the map expands, it becomes increasingly difficult to remember the ever-expanding wishlist of specific tile arrangements you're waiting for. It also takes longer and longer to find the correct place to put a tile as the number of possible placements continually increases. The result of this is that the pace of the game drags and the game increasingly feels like a tedious administrative chore. This problem could be fixed by having a button you can click in order to highlight any particularly good locations for a tile (e.g. 3+ matching sides). 

2. The number of possible tile combinations is so high that the chances of getting the right tile combination become very slim, particularly once you have more than 3 sides to match. This leads to a sense of frustration which is at odds with the intended relaxing game experience. This problem could be fixed by including a new type of tile - a wildcard tile - which automatically morphs into the perfect tile once placed. This could be a special quest reward, for example, or perhaps could be awarded each time you achieve a certain number of natural perfect placements.

3. The mechanics of the river and railway tiles are fiddly and frustrating. The difficult of managing these pieces, combined with the ridiculous water station tile, means that the only viable tactic is to create an area just for them on one edge of the map. This leads to an unnatural and aesthetically displeasing map. These tiles should be removed as base tiles and instead should be overlay tiles that you place on top of existing tiles (as in Civilization V). This would not only alleviate issues 1 and 2 above, but could allow for more variety of quests (e.g. a quest to connect two closed town areas with a railway, a quest to create a railway which bridges over two different rivers or spans a large area of water, a quest to create a river which travels through three pure forest tiles, etc.).

4. The gameplay is fundamentally just not interesting enough. More thought needs to be put into how to make a game which has mechanics beyond tile rotation. This game needs things special base tiles which actually do something (as opposed to being purely cosmetic), overlay tiles that go on top of existing tiles to allow placement of rivers, railways and roads, a greater variety of quests, maybe even power-ups which could be won by closing an area (e.g. dynamite to destroy a previously placed tile, an axe to turn forest into plains, etc.), etc.

There is the foundation of a good game here, but it needs significantly more development to make it enjoyable to play.

146693110.review: While many copy cats have emerged since Dorfromantik, this romantic village puzzle game has paved the way as a classic. The various landscapes, differing biomes, and complex quests and challenges keep the game fresh. The colored tiles are ever-changing and random allowing enhanced strategy, though the game can be as relaxing and cozy or as challenging as you'd like (especially if you want the achievements related to not rotating the tiles). 146254685.review:
A fantastic terrain building tile game. You build little towns, woods, fields, rivers, lakes etc. by rotating and placing down terrain / building tiles to slowly create your own mosaic-style world map. 

The challenge is to match the tile sides up as best as you can to get more points. You get points for completing these quests and for matching as many sides as possible up to all of them being a perfect placement. Also, to try to avoid running out of tiles by completing the little "quests". Which are to match up over a certain number of tiles e.g. connect 10 field tiles. Or, more difficultly, matching up an exact number of tiles you can't exceed.  Which tests your overall planning power! 

The aesthetic is a bit reminiscent of the Catan board game, very cutesy and simple bright colour palette. The ambient music is very peaceful and the sound effects when you click a tile down are very satisfying. 

All in all, very addicting and meditative game to play when you're not sure what to do with a few hours. 9/10

"Dorfromantik" is an absolutely enchanting experience that mixes tile-placement strategy with peaceful world-building. You're handed a stack of hexagonal tiles featuring various landscape elements like forests, fields, and rivers, and it's up to you to create your own sprawling, harmonious landscape. The art is gorgeously whimsical, and the calming background music makes it feel like a meditative retreat.

What really makes the game stand out is its accessibility matched with underlying complexity. On one hand, it’s a laid-back game that allows you to create picturesque tableaus at your own pace. On the other, there are missions, challenges, and combos that bring a strategic depth to the gameplay. Each tile placement matters, affecting your score and future options, so you're constantly engaged.

If you're a fan of puzzle games or just need a tranquil escape from real-world chaos, "Dorfromantik" is a must-play. It’s the perfect blend of casual relaxation and engaging strategy, making it easy to lose hours in its captivating, ever-expanding landscapes. 🏞️🧩

145063916.review:
This is a funny game. Better said, this is a game that has funny tags. If you look up above at the most relevant tags you see "City Builder", "Turn Based Strategy" and "Puzzle". Of those three I'd say only puzzle is 100% relevant. Especially in terms of what you'd really expect from these tags traditionally. When you think "City Builder" you normally think of games like Tropico, Cities: Skylines or Simcity. Yes, you can build a very large town by connecting lots of house tiles that could constitute a city, but it's not what you think it is. Same goes for Turn-Based Strategy yeah, you lay down one tile at a time. So one could call that a turn. But it's not like Civilisation or Total War where there are clearly defined turns as such.

That being said, was this a delightful discovery? Absolutely! It's addictive, soothing and simply fun. This game is to me, a classic example of "don't judge a book by it's cover" and "you should really give a wide net of games a go!". While I do enjoy board games and this game very much feels like one, it certainly was not what I was expecting. And it turned out to be an incredibly pleasant surprise!

The graphics and feel of the game are all very lovely. My only criticism is the music. I think it's ok, but honestly, I think they could have been a bit more adventurous with it and gone with something a bit more melodic rather than something that feels like it would play in the background at a spa. Like I get what they were going for, they wanted something calming and inoffensive to try to appeal to as many people as possible, but I don't generally agree with this sort of thinking. Things designed by committee are rarely good. I think they should have let the composer be a bit more adventurous.

All in all. Very solid game that definitely deserves the overwhelmingly positive reviews it currently enjoys! Recommended!

144960487.review:
A lot of the reviews for this game paint it as a chill, calm, no-stress puzzle game. And it could be played that way, if you didn't care about the score, unlocking additional challenges, or completing quests. If, however, you're the kind of person who does care about your score, unlocking additional challenges, or completing quests, it's a stress-filled RNG nightmare. You start with six quest types (or challenges) unlocked, and as you progress through the game you can reach preset tiles on the map and complete their quests to unlock a new quest type (or challenge).

For instance, you may encounter a preset tile with a bit of forest and a quest to connect 500+ trees to it, and if you succeed at the quest you can unlock one of the remaining challenges. It doesn't seem to matter what kind of quest tile you encounter when it comes to unlocking the next challenge, and no consideration of which quest tiles have been placed at map generation is made when the game rolls your starting tileset. This is where the problem comes in. You can run into a til that wants 40 or 50 more field tiles attached to it, but the rest of the game you get primarily water or forest tiles, or city tiles, or even meadows, and you can just never complete that quest. This can go on for game, after game, after game, with no end in sight.

Pure RNG like this just ruins games, and it's such an easy fix, that games like this wind up infuriating me, rather than providing enjoyment or relaxation. So if you care about the score, the leader boards, or you're a completionist, I'd advise steering clear of this one.

143747574.review:
Dorfromantik achieves what it sets out to do; it is a thoroughly engaging, minimalist, game perfect for when you need a little mental decompression, but still want to build something in the process. It feels a bit like making a sand mandala or working in a mini zen garden, only gamified just enough to give you some direction if you are not feeling purely artistic. Laying the tiles with the lite incentive of matching like hexagonal faces and completing the occasional "mission" to have X trees in a contiguous forest, etc, is never so intense that it causes stress.

Whats best for the FOMOphobes and 4x completion out there that struggle to  actually stop after "one more turn" You walk away anytime and there is nothing to remember when you come back, you don't even need to actively save the game. Better yet, theirs no draw back to starting over either.

Dorfromantik has just enough challenge that I don't zone out, but I focus on it and stop thinking about anything else, and it's really relaxing. Not only is it a ton of fun (as well as fulfilling, knocking out task after task) but it's a great way for me to wind down in the evenings before I go to bed. I really thought I would like this game, and I did enjoy it at first. After about an hour, though, I realized it was not relaxing me as expected but was stressing me out. There is a constant push and pull between new quests asking you to expand biomes and existing quests asking you to close biomes off. I never quite got the satisfaction of completion, because the goalposts kept getting farther away, and as the map got bigger and bigger it became harder to juggle the competing objectives. It was really hard for me to stop playing, but not in a fun way, and eventually I just needed to quit and walk away.

142370216.review: Casual puzzle game with hidden depths. Place tiles down on an a playing area to slowly construct a map, with periodic challenges set by the game to build chains of contiguous tile sets. The hexagonal pieces score points for corresponding with matching tiles (the egde of one tile with trees if placed adjoining another tile with trees scores points) with the objective being to construct something that is randomly generated but aesthetically pleasing. Your enjoyment will go as far as how much you enjoy pushing yourself for high scores - or enjoying the free play mode to build a world of pure imagination.

142369688.review: I really want to like this game, but I found it stressful to try to optimize tile placement and make a nice looking town.  They'll throw in random train tracks at times that don't make sense, and they're incredibly hectic, like a four way intersection, so you end up cobbling random things together in places you don't want to, and your town doesn't look anything like the pictures.  Ultimately, the game is very one dimensional -- they could have integrated systems to allow you more flexibility in tile placement while still retaining the core themes of the puzzle.  E.g. some sort of tile inventory, more flexibility on tile placement, something where the puzzle edges aren't all fixed and can be adjusted, allow you to cycle through tiles, etc.  Edit:  They could also add a system where it is easier to see when a tile placement is optimal, because if you're trying to be careful and strategically place your tiles, it's extremely tedious to find optimal placements when your board is large -- again some happy medium between doing it for you and being able to help filter information so it's not so tedious.

141933831.review:
[h1][b]Relaxing with Basic Simplification[/b][/h1]

This is one of the most relaxing games you can play without being mind-numbing like solitaire.  Everything is simple and not overstimulating. With multiple modes and a wide variety of different biomes.  Biome being one of the most complicated words used. It does not use a wide variety of colors to distract the player. At times, I'm totally engrossed that I'm sitting up in my chair and calculating every move. Other times, I've been able to sit back, play while watching TV or simply falling asleep.  I've even played this game while I'm sitting in the queue to go into a dungeon or raid while playing World of Warcraft (WOW). It's that simple to play or to get involved with. 

With a creative, easy, and hard mode, there is something for everyone. 

This game does not take a major computer to run. I have had this running at the same time several major other programs and WOW at the same time. This takes up so little CPU and requires there are really no GPU requirements, it will fit in on the most basic computer.

[hr][/hr]

Teachers & Parents Will Find This Educational

This game requires some thought be given to the placement of tiles and the ability to assess your decision and count what the results are going to be. There is basic hints along the way with an undo ability built in for fixing a misplaced tile.  This is common sense for adults who have been through basic middle school. On the other hand students as young as kindergarten and who can count will find this game fun with the long run of being beneficial to their growth. 

With all math you need the ability to understand a mathematical equation, understand the order of operations and then work on the answer. From basic math to advanced balancing of chemical formulas its a matter of understanding what to do first and where your move one part of the answer to the next. 

This game does the same thing. With smaller numbers but it can teach a student to do fast thinking because the flags in the game tell you yes, no, or what your placement could calculate, to if you place the tile there. The same thing we teach students. We have children/students use pencils because they can erase the answer when they are wrong. Calculate your numbers really quickly before you give you final answer.  With a

It also teaches you to slow down. It is not a speed game, it is a matter of evaluating your options.  With a basic theme and no multiple scenarios i.e. water and transit for humans, it allows a younger player to learn and evaluate. 

It has the a 'Jackpot Pavlovian System' built in to allow for the student to be excited about what they have done and wanting to play more. It also has a scoring system which between siblings or students would encourage challenges and an eagerness to do better.  Younger children will only see they are being allowed to play a game, not as a chore. 

The game is on Steam. All younger children want to be like their parents and older siblings. Steam is considered the adult place to get games. Younger children will see it as a treat or reward, while adults will know they are learning something from games. 

This game could easily be placed in the educational category to increase audience size.  I would highly recommend the producers of the game to offer this to school districts for educational purposes.  As a professional sales person and account manager this game could easily be packaged and sold to school districts - parents would buy it for their children based on a recommendation from a school district.  

[b]PTA SUPPORT[/b] I spent eleven years for all my children's school PTAs. I served as a board member, auction chair, Ways and Means Vice President and finally as President. If any of the teachers or math departments from my schools had asked me to supplement their curriculum with this game, I would have easily put this to a motion and gotten approval. 

Thank you for producing such a wonderful game.

How to enjoy Dorfromantik

Don't expect getting high score always. If you do that you really hate RNG tiles although that's the core of the game. Should aim for an average score always.

140885083.review:
Not worth your time. I regret the hours I put into this game. 

I say this as someone who has scored 54,000+ points on a run, which places me above the top ~3% of players approximately, judging from the global achievement stats.

At first glance you may mistake Dorfromantik as some sort of chill city builder, but it actually is a very not-chill rogue-like jigsaw puzzler. The twist over a normal jigsaw is that you are allowed to "misplace" the pieces, e.g. the terrain depicted on an edge of the hex piece doesn't have to match the neighboring pieces. However, only "perfect" placements (where all 6 edges have a matching neighbor) grant you an extra piece to play with, and stave off your inevitable death.  

And therein lies my central complaint of the game: Poor UI when it comes to perfect placements. As you play and build out the puzzle, the number of gaps in it will steadily increase as your surrounding terrain restricts appropriate placements. A single hex hole will only have 1 perfect matching piece after all, and there tens of thousands of terrain combinations (albeit some are more common than others). It's up to you to keep a mental list of all the combinations you need, vs what's currently in your hand. 

Fine. What's frustrating is that you'll eventually forced to place a non-perfect tile to achieve a mission or just survive for another piece placement, and these ruined tiles are nearly indistinguishable from the perfect ones. You may think you have the exact piece for a given opening, only to find out you don't get as many perfect placements as you originally thought (or any at all). In my final run I was so fed up with this trial-and-error, that I eventually just slammed down my pieces to end the game, even though I could have spent more time finding more optimal placements to continue playing and get a higher score.

If there was a clearer indicator in the UI for marking non-perfect tiles, that would greatly relieve the montony and stress of filling in the gaps, as the barrier for finding a sufficient neighboring piece is greatly reduced.

Other thoughts:
[list]
[*]Matching terrain can sometimes be difficult to tell due to irregularity in the representation (related to the problem above). But at the very least matching edges light up white when you're testing piece placement.
[*]The unlocks and general progression could be more enticing. They're all just reskins, that's it. The biomes are pretty cool as they change the palette of a region via a gradient, but the rest are features that are so small that you're not really going to notice them on a large map. And they tend to be samey anyway.
[*]A "session" or run takes quite a long time. My 18 hours recorded was only from two sessions after the tutorial. If you play cautiously and optimally you'll live longer, but also the gameplay becomes a slog as you have infinitely-increasing choices of where to place tiles.
[/list]

There was some fun to be had, but overall Dorfromantik is a stressful chore.

Peaceful, relaxing and highly enjoyable. Kind of like a solo version of Carcassonne (a great boardgame) but more sprawling - a single, well-played game of Dorfromantik can go on for hours. But the game is so easy-going that even when looking to maximise the points for every tile placement, it never gets stressful. 
Before playing the game I watched a couple of reviews that criticised it for a perceived lack of direct goals and for the "luck-of-the-draw" element of the tile drawing. I'm glad I picked it up despite those reviews - those criticisms haven't been an issue for me. There are goals throughout and it's left up to the player how they want to approach them and which goals they want to pursue. And the game is no more "lucky" than any boardgame that features tile-drawing. And as with any of those other tile placement games, there are many ways to mitigate the luck (and rack up higher and higher scores).
This is definitely a game I'll keep coming back to.

139880986.review:
Relaxing? Yes, but also... strangely stressful. Under this whole aesthetic of idyllic central European countryside there's a surprisingly deep game of matching tile edges, managing groups, closing off regions, fulfilling quests. You can, of course, ignore all of that and play creative mode exclusively, but I'd feel like this would be a waste of game.

There are two reasons to pay attention to these systems. One - score. That one might not seem that important, but it's fun to try to beat your own high score! Besides, it often leads to achievements, which in turn unlock new tiles and biomes. And two - it replenishes your tile pool. See, your pile of tiles is always limited - and once you run out, it's [strike]game over[/strike] session complete. So if you want to keep expanding your little world, you have to keep paying attention to these things.

The mixture of those systems and the incredibly chill aesthetic - both in terms of look and the soundscape - create a very unique and potent brew that just washes your worries away. And I think this is the main reason why the game is so beloved by many.

For example: this one time, I had a mental breakdown so severe, my entire concept of reality collapsed and even thoughts of suicide didn't bring any solace. I got out of it with the help of therapy, philosophy and some research, but what kept the mortifying existential dread at bay was this game. The chill feeling was strong enough to make me forget I spent too long gazing into the abyss, and undoubtedly made my recovery quicker.

With all that said, I wish the game had more object types on the tiles. There are only 3 common ones (there's more, but they're much less common): houses, trees, and fields. I get it, that's rural Europe for you, but we also have mountains! Meadows! Swamps! Admittedly, the devs are from Berlin (I think), and the state of Brandenburg is almost completely flat - so maybe that's what they were going for.

I wasn't sure if I'd like Dorfromantik, but it entered my life when I needed it, and returned some kind of peace to my soul. I won't claim it would do the same to you, but I'd say it's nice to place a few tiles every now and then.

139771349.review: Nice, relaxing experience, but after a while it gets repetitive, boring and even tiny bit frustrating. While I've had quite a bit of fun playing the game, I couldn't stop thinking how this game could be better. I like its visual style, changing biomes, those little ships and trains cruising through the map. Dorfromantic has relaxing atmosphere and brings joy from looking at those unique lands you can build there. But also I was always a bit frustrated because I couldn't really find any special strategy that could help me survive longer in a game. At some point you just get not enough new tasks and start to slowly spend more tiles than you are awarded with. So often after each completed task you wait for new one to start and you waste tiles waiting for it to show up. So many times you have like 3 field tasks, 2 with water, and all the tiles with forrest/city/train tracks are just waste. New tiles are 100% randomized and you're never awarded with tiles that you need - which would be great idea - you can either get lucky (rarely, due to high number of possible combinations), wait for ages for 100% matching tile or simply use one that matches partially. It would be so cool to get a special tile as an award - one that can be placed in any place and will fit all surrounding tiles. Or if you could swap current tile with different one. No. Obviously carefully considering each move can prolong the game, but eventually you will run out of tiles anyway. And while this is intentioned - what I don't like is the fact that final result is mostly dependent on that random nature of the game. If you scored higher than usual - it's luck, not your newly invented strategy or smart decisions. So it quickly becomes boring, as I don't see any incentive to play again if it's just luck that can get me further than before. It's definately worth checking out, spending some time with it, but the novelty and discovery evaporate quite fast and you're left with a bit of disappointment.

139238812.review:
HISTORIA:

· Dorfromantik es un juego relajante y pacífico que se centra en la construcción de aldeas y en la creación de un hermoso entorno natural. 

· Es perfecto para todos aquellos que buscan un juego tranquilo y sin presiones en el que puedan relajarse y disfrutar de la belleza de la naturaleza.

CONTENIDO:

· El objetivo del juego es construir y desarrollar una aldea en un entorno rural y natural. Para hacerlo, se nos irán dando fichas hexagonales con diferentes tipos de paisajes, como campos, bosques, ríos, montañas, etc.

· Las ficha se van consumiendo y la partida termina cuando nos quedamos en cero, pero para evitar esto, tendremos distintos tipos de desafios, que al completarlos nos recompensan con mas fichas durante la partida.

· Existen varios modo de juegos: Por objetivo de puntos,  modo libre (nos permite crear nuestro ecosistema con fichas ilimitadas) y un modo de desafio diario que nos dará distintas recompensas.

LO BUENO:

+ City builder original.

+ Relajante. Ideal para jugar mientras escuchas un podcast o video de fondo.

+ La música, la ambientación, los colores. 

+ Ideal para partidas cortas.


LO MALO:

- Poca variedad de fichas al comienzo.

- Falta de online (seria interesante verlo en un futuro).

- Se siente poco rejugable despues de varias partidas.

138371607.review:
I gave this one a thumb up, but it's not a resounding success either.
DorfRomantik is a special kind of 'Candy Crush', except, in place of geometrical shapes, you have landscape elements (fields, forests, trains, water, grassland, and houses). As advertised, the mood is peaceful, and the pace of the game allows for a relaxing experience, supported by a calm and soothing soundtrack.
However, the built-in randomness ensures every landscape you build will devolve into a monstrosity. What makes landscapes relaxing is their underlying 'humanity', so when your creation turns 'inhumane', relaxation *can* go out the window. Also, as long as the music sticks to saxophones parts reminiscent of a Christopher Cross song, no problem. But when you suddenly have machine-guns roaring in your head because the next piano track is oddly evocative of the intro to that horrendous 'Man of Steel' theme...
That said, I feel like DorfRomantik somehow met its goals. It [b]is[/b] peaceful, and it sucks you in like a Solitaire (seriously, watch the clock when you play), but in a richer, somewhat less repetitive environment. And there are now different options that really let you play it the way you want to, including a 'sandbox' builder. 
So, in the end, despite its drawbacks, DorfRomantik is a game that will fit nicely in your Library next to titles like "Wingspan" or "Eastshade".

PS: watch the second video up there; it's literally a 3.30min demo showing you the [b]whole[/b] game, including a good tutorial.

137806721.review:
Strongly recommend this game. It's extremely easy to pick up and understand, since it's got only a couple of core mechanics. You place tiles on a map, you rotate the tiles to match edge to like-edge, and you aim to complete quests and get perfect matches, all in an effort to never run out of tiles.

The game is great casually due to its ease of learning, but it can quickly expand to whatever depths you care to play it at. The maps can get complex and out of hand fast, and every decision matters if you want to push yourself. The music is relaxing, the game is easy to open and close, and it'll scratch a little itch you didn't know you had. Sessions can last a long time if you get good enough, so be ready for the game to consume you if you want to engage with it on a deeper level.

137804546.review:
I hate this game like you wouldn't believe. It acts all friendly like it's some sort of relaxing chill hex game but it's just a visage to slowly grind away your sanity in what ultimately amounts to a massive waste of the minutes you have left in your life.

Oh, Dorf Romantik, you sly, deceiving little devil, luring me in with your adorable hand-painted graphics and soothing soundtrack. How could I ever resist? But just as I let my guard down, you unleash the hidden beast within.

You claim to be a "relaxing building strategy and puzzle game," but what you really are is a tactical mastermind that feasts upon my feeble attempts at creating idyllic landscapes. Yes, I see through your ruse, Dorf Romantik. You're not fooling me any longer.

Sure, the game starts off easy enough, lulling me into a false sense of accomplishment as I place tiles, creating quaint little villages and serene forests. But then, out of nowhere, you hit me with these so-called "quests" – the windmill that demands six grain fields or the deer that wants a 50-tree forest. Well, guess what, Dorf Romantik? I don't negotiate with terrorists.

And let's talk about those "unlockable tiles and biomes," shall we? Oh, how exciting it must be to discover new lands, filled with new challenges! Except, you know what I don't need? More challenges. I have enough of those in my life already. If I wanted to feel the crushing weight of my own inadequacy, I'd just check my bank account or try to assemble IKEA furniture.

Oh, and don't even get me started on the high score system. You mean to tell me that not only do I have to suffer through this relentless hexagonal hellscape, but I also have to compete against others for the highest score? What kind of sick, twisted game are you playing, Dorf Romantik?

But perhaps the most egregious sin of all is the undo button and rotating the last tile to not lose. Yeah instead of losing my mind over the placement of a stupid lake tile, I could just enter creative mode but again there's the score I have to worry about.

In conclusion, Dorf Romantik is a heartless, diabolical game that masquerades as a calm, peaceful retreat from the chaos of life. But don't be fooled, my friends. It's a hex-shaped nightmare that will slowly, mercilessly grind your sanity into dust. You have been warned.

137775246.review:
In need of a really nice chill game? This game is for you.
It is not a game you would play end to end in a sitting. It is one you would play it over multiple sessions when you just want to relax. 
Gameplay
In the beginning, you start with a stack of random tiles. The idea is to match as many as you can together to expand your playing field. You will be challenged to keep the groups together to reap the rewards of more tiles for you stack to keep you playing further. The challenge then is do you close out a group, or risk it for further rewards. Also occasionally in game play, you will extend you tiles outwards and a greyed out special tile will appear approx 10 tiles from the current edge of your tiled map. If you build to these before your tile stack diminishes you will be given a new tile type.

137760831.review:
What a fantastic game! You can pick it up just to relax and build a little Dorf (village) without worrying about perfection, or, when you're feeling analytical, strive to perfectly place every tile. There are a few different gameplay styles (encouraged by leveled achievements), and to truly master the game, you'll need to learn them all - or you'll run out of tiles and the game ends.

Perfection will result in lots of snaking connected fields, like farmlands or forests, while you hunt for the perfect tile to connect them. Placing those perfect pieces will earn additional tiles.

Caring less about perfection will have you focusing on completing quests, closing fields to get flags, and exploring to find bonus tiles. All will give you additional tiles.

Or, just play creative mode, where you have an endless supply of tiles, can skip tiles you don't like, and can generate perfect tiles to place in any spot.

I like making enough train tracks that I get choo choos, and seeing how weird of a water body I can make. 

A+

Overall, I highly recommend Dorfromantik to anyone looking for a relaxing, visually stunning game that's easy to pick up and play. It's the perfect way to unwind after a long day, and you'll find yourself coming back to it time and time again.

137416995.review:
Dorfromantik is barely a game... it's a console (Switch) game that should probably have been a mobile app.  It's selling point is that it's "casual" which means "incredibly shallow" in terms of gameplay.  The idea is that you create an idyllic village scene by placing various tiles around.  In an attempt to make some kind of game out of this objectiveless sandbox, there's a few limits to what you can and can't do... you can run out of tiles, and you've given what seem to be procedurally generated "quests" that just involve specific arrangements of tiles (like placing three tiles with "forest" edges together, how challenging).  You might as well play dominos with only one player, that's pretty much what we're dealing with here, only slightly more visually appealing.

From a technical perspective, the game doesn't meet basic minimum requirements that most PC gamers expect as standard, there's some minor technical foibles that aren't helping.

The game features lazy low-polygon "retro" assets, making this look like a barely functional 3D game from the mid 2000s.  It's unclear why the developers weren't able to arrange high quality, high polygon count contemporary assets for the game, and also irrelevant... what matters is that this looks bad as a result of their decisions, a compromise PC gamers shouldn't have to put up with.

Because this is a console game, it carries a number of deliberate design deficiencies.  Compromises were made to cater to the inferior console gaming appliances that the game was designed for.  These are unfortunate compromises and limitations that PC gamers shouldn't be forced to accept, but it's evident that PC was a second thought for the console-centric developers.  The game is deficient as a result of these choices, and would have been so much better without the handicaps that designing games for consoles forces upon a game.  Once more, console peasants have made gaming worse for everyone.

This looks and feels like a mobile app, but it doesn't seem to have made it to the app stores.  It's unclear why this was put on Steam/Nintendo Switch instead of the app stores it seems to have been designed for.  Maybe it was removed, maybe it was rejected by Apple and Google (they do have more rigorous quality standards than Valve does for Steam, after all).

Regardless, for all intents and purposes "Dorfromantik" might as well be a mobile app, it has the same limitations and dumbed down qualities.  It's impossible to recommend such a game to PC gamers.  We don't spend all this money building gaming rigs so we can pretend they're iPhones and play games that might as well be mobile apps.

These technical defects push this game below acceptable standards for any modern PC game.

Another unusual point, the software contains stock/store assets and other packages, but the "developer" here hasn't credited the people who actually did the work for the software (a scarecrow asset, a number of Unity packages for UI and graphical effects and so on).  While this isn't necessarily against the license for the use of those assets, and it's not an unusual practice for this kind of code reuse, claiming the work of others as your own without crediting them (I checked the credits) is highly unethical.

All of that might be forgiven, but the pricing can't be.  Dorfromantik has the almost comically optimistic (if it wasn't so sad) price of $14 USD (plus TWO soundtrack DLC's for $6, making this games true cost a whopping $28 USD, near AAA pricing), for which you could easily get any number of recent AAA games.  The developer seems to genuinely think this is a better game and thus should cost more than the entire Mass Effect trilogy, The Witcher 3, Subnautica, Deep Rock Galactic, the list goes on.  I know, right?

You wanna talk about city building?  This costs more than Cities: Skylines!!!

This is also competing with over 9,000 free games available on Steam, many of them far better than this massively overpriced product.  Given the defects and quality issues with the software, coupled with the unrealistic price, and the questionable ethical nature of the developer and/or their associates (as outlined above), this is impossible to recommend.

The developers of Dorfromantic have shown remarkable dedication to their community. 137302974.review:
Cosy yet addictive tile-based builder where the goal is simply to build a peaceful, bucolic landscape with as high a score as possible. 

You start with a fixed number of hexagonal tiles. Each tile can have some combination of grass, field, trees, houses, water or train track. You proceed to fit them together one-by-one, creating a landscape in the process. The size of your stack of tiles dictates how big a landscape you can build. Initially, not that big it would seem. However, you are given 'quests' as you proceed (build a forest with this many tress, a town with this many houses, a river this long etc), and as you complete these quests, you will gain more score and new tiles will be added to your stack allowing you to extend your landscape further. And this is really it. Once the stack is empty, it is over and you are left with a wonderful landscape and a high-score to chase. 

Simple but with just the right amount of engagement to make it fun but not so much to ever make it stressful. The art style is wonderful, the animations are relaxing, the music is chill. Runs can last from 30 mins to a couple of hours depending on well you are doing (but you can suspend at anytime and resume later). Also works wonderfully on Steamdeck. Highly recommended.

137301568.review:
Steam told me I might like this game based on other games I've played. Steam was correct. Easy to pickup, tough to master.

Tiles have 6 sides and a handful of things that can go on a tile (as far as I can tell they're randomly generated) so it's up to you to find the best spot for whichever tile you're served until you're out. Two kinds of quests pop up as you play, either prompting you to link a certain amount of stuff together (like, link 10 trees together as an example), or having you close off what you've already made with the proper tile type. Completing quests gets you more tiles, more tiles gets you more points, and that's the loop.

My high score after 14 hours was about 14,000 - which felt like a herculean task and an impossible feat (I told my wife about it at dinner knowing she wouldn't care but I was THAT excited) - however I've seen numbers much higher and I'm actually quite low on the leader board. I don't believe there will be a day that will pass by without me playing at least one round.

137298941.review:
TL;DR: Boring. Overpriced. Missed potential.

As I approached the end of the first level I just put tiles wherever, to finish quickly and get to the next level. [b]But there is no next level.[/b] It's the same one, over and over. There's some unlocks, but not enough to hold interest.

At this price point I expected a full game, but this feels like a basic tablet app, or the "casual mode" to a more fleshed-out game.

[h3]Potential[/h3]

Here's where this review gets long. I'm gonna talk about how much potential this game has, and share some ideas, because tbh that's what makes it so disappointing, how much more it could have been.

It could have:

- New levels with their own challenges, restrictions, reskinned tiles, and special tiles unique to that level or area. Eg, a city area with factory tiles instead of farm tiles and trams instead of trains; a beach biome with more water tiles and no farms; a fairy kingdom with oversized mushrooms and dragonfly flight routes instead of train tracks; a zoo world where you get bonus points for grouping birds/mammals/fish etc, or a theme park world where massive roller coasters replace train tracks... there's endless possibilities with this game's engine.

- More mechanics besides "put tree next to tree", eg. bonus points if you put a train station next to a village of >10 houses, or if you connect villages via railways. Atm you're incentivised to keep everything separate, [i]especially[/i] train tracks which heavily restrict their adjacent tiles.

- Having a choice between 2 tiles would be great. I actually enjoyed the game for a while when I was imagining how I would build the area, with its history and current culture -- but despite being simple, the system is too restrictive to give you any lasting sense of creative freedom. Having a choice of 2 tiles instead of 1 would give players a feeling of control and authorship, and let them steer the direction of their current world so each new one feels less repetitive, without disrupting the core score chasing mechanic too much. (Yes, there's a Creative Mode, but I need some restrictions and goals to keep me interested and motivated).

There's [i]just so much[/i] you could do with this game's concept, I could go on for ages with other ideas. I'm still gonna try another run, maybe try to unlock everything and see if my opinion changes, but as said, atm this feels like either an app store game or an early access build.

I've only played this for about an hour.  I don't know how well it scales to expert play or anything.

What I've experienced, though, is an incredibly intuitive and relaxing gameplay loop, like figuring out (the board game version of; the video game adaptation lacks the original's charm) Carcassonne as you go, finding out along an exceeding undemanding, gentle curve how to improve your score, which conveniently seems to be 99% the same as how to achieve a harmonious arrangement of your pieces.

I got this in a bundle, and have already absolutely gotten my money's worth.  I would feel like I've already gotten my money's worth at a sale price of $5 or so, and I have a strong sense that this is going to continue to pay relaxing, interesting dividends.

You build a world hex by hex.  You get points by matching edges to create organic, satisfying landscapes.  There are added "quests" that offer you more complex, high-scoring objectives.  This should be a no-brainer if you enjoy similar congruence-based gameplay loops, like that of Carcassonne, or of Coatsink's ISLANDERS or 
Oskar Stålberg's Townscaper, the latter two of which it currently shares a "Serene City-Builder Bundle."

The music is lovely.  The graphics are low-poly cottagecore. Great work, Toukana Interactive— I'll be watching what you do next.

136959303.review:
Dorfromantik is a very laid back game.  There isn't a story line or even an ultimate goal.  There are quests and points, but ultimately they don't matter.  The object of the game is to create a landscape however you want with the tiles that you're given.  Sure you can produce your own goals like try to play as long as possible by earning more tiles, or scoring the most points possible, or try to unlock all the tiles that the game has to offer, but at its core this game is a creative endeavor to do the best you can with what you have. 

I can see the appeal of the game if you want something just to pass the time with.  The game is pretty, and the music is soothing.  But ultimately, for me, the payoffs of the game just aren't enough for me to want to keep playing.  Honestly it does feel like a .99 game you might find on an app store under "relaxing sim/puzzler" but sim and puzzler is used rather loosely here.  There is no real simulation of people, no economy, no resource gathering beyond tiles.... It's a terrain generation game.  

 There are goals and quests....  Each tile is hexagonal, and each side has a "biome."  You can line up biomes together to make larger villages.  Some terrains have hard rules like railroads restrict the end of the tile to only railroads.  Some tiles come with quests where you might need to connect 100 forest together in a continuous chain/blob, others ask that you get precisely X houses no more or less.  Sometimes there is a tile in the distance that is highlighted that you're supposed to build and connect to.  You get extra points for placing a tile that perfectly matches the biome to its 6 neighbors. The tiles, as far as I can tell are randomly generated, so you have to work with what you have if you want to maximize your score.  Some events like getting a perfect match gives you more tiles, but you start off with 100 tiles.  When you run out of tiles, the game is over, and you start over, with anything you've unlocked from the previous playthroughs.  There really isn't any penalty for not matching biomes up well, nor failing to complete quest objectives.  

There are also a creative mode which lets you generate/change the tiles to whatever you want so you can paint the map to how you like, stripping all of the loose game mechanics entirely from the game.  So if it frustrates you that the game "ends" you can turn that off.  

I can see how this game can appeal to a certain kind of game player in a certain mood, but ultimately, this game is not for me.

135911613.review:
So, I've been playing this off and on after work as a way to relax and get into something simple that helps me to relax; which, to be honest... is probably exactly what this was intended to be and I love it for that.

It's a puzzle game where you attempt to match up tiles with towns, fields, forests, rivers, and railroads in order to up your score. As you fulfill certain quests (like x amount of forest tiles strung together) you acquire more tiles. Line up a tile on all sides with the corresponding tiles? You get another tile. Eventually you WILL run out of tiles but the objective is to rack up your score while simultaneously keeping as many tiles as you can coming back to your stockpile therefore keeping you in the game longer and further increasing that overall score.

It's an easy-to-grasp (and jump into) premise but addictive and thoroughly enjoyable with endearing graphics, audio, and musical score. I highly recommend for those who like puzzle games at all and need something to relax to!

Dorfromantik is a peaceful building strategy and puzzle game where you create a beautiful and ever-growing village landscape by placing tiles. You can explore a variety of colorful biomes, discover and unlock new tiles and complete quests to fill your world with life! It's a relaxing game that allows you to immerse yourself in a quiet, peaceful world at any time and take a break from everyday life. It's perfect for those who enjoy games like Catan and other tile-based games.

In Dorfromantik, you start with a few tiles and have to build a landscape from hexagonal tiles. You can create pine forests, patchwork fields, meandering rivers, spidery train tracks, and higgledy-piggledy little red-brick towns.  You can choose from a variety of biomes and discover and unlock new tiles.  

The game has a relaxing soundtrack that helps you unwind while playing.  It's perfect for those who want to take a break from their busy lives and enjoy a peaceful game.

I liked the game initially, I really did. And I still do love the quaint visuals and how the world comes together as you build it. But soon I realised that the game didn't really have the depth to achieve any of the goals I wanted from it.

As a relaxing game it fails because your continent soon grows too big to manage effectively and then you'll find your game ending sooner than you'd like because you ran out of pieces. You have the ability to port your game over to sandbox mode, which is nice, but by default it automatically borks up the colours and alienates your world from you. And by removing all the quests and connection bonuses alongside the introduction of the tool that'll make pieces, it instantly gives you a sense of pointlessness. What I really wanted was to just have the regular game continue. Let me go into piece 'debt' and continue playing because I want to accomplish all those quests. Or just give me 10 extra pieces and a slap on the wrist and say I didn't get the gold medal. Whatever, at least I still have a reason to keep playing...

As an engaging puzzle game it also dropped off for me because I realised I was just doing a computer's job. It's not very difficult to constantly scan the exterior of your board and compare the next piece to all the available slots. I made myself a document containing data on all of the available placements on my board and what each side required. Then when I got a new piece I could just look at my spreadsheet and it'd tell me if this piece fills any of the holes I needed it to. If you could communicate the game data to an AI, it could play this game. Which means it's not really a game, nor a puzzle. It's just work.

I mean look, I have 20 hours on the game, the game's $20 aud when not on sale. It's not the worst purchase you'll make but idk. Just left a sour taste in my mouth.

135373701.review: Absolutely enchanting little puzzle that knows exactly what it wants to be and succeeds at being that with flourish and taste. It feels extremely board-gamey to me, landing in a lovely niche right between Carcasonne's tile placement mechanics and Calico's hex-based puzzle elements. Dorfromantik scratches just the right itches for me for a thinky tile game with nice aesthetics and casual vibes but deep strategy and a long - but not unlimited - lifespan per game.Progression is tied to score (as far as I can tell, having not played much and avoided spoilers for anything that might unlock down the line) and all game modes seem to be available from the outset, which means that [i]actually playing the game[/i] is the core gameplay loop rather than unlocking or achievement hunting. That, sadly, is an often overlooked element of design especially in games with roguelite progression systems, which this technically has, but Dorfromantik neatly sidesteps that by being a good, fun game first and allowing for progression as a nice cosmetic bonus for skilled play.All around excellent, and while I don't think it's probably for absolutely everybody I do think absolutely everybody should give it a try before deciding, because it's utterly wonderful.

135344947.review: Fantastic game for what it is: Casual, relaxing, a modicum of puzzle gameplay and the feeling of setting up an itty bitty diorama of a town.[hr][/hr]I usually put this game on when I have a migraine or need to sit through a work from home meeting that I don't have anything to contribute towards. It's absolutely perfect for that, and if it sounds enticing I highly recommend it.[hr][/hr]The gameplay consists of placing 6-sided tiles that randomly have different attributes on each side. You link up waterways, plains, houses, railways, forests, and blank areas together and get bonuses for connecting certain amounts of tiles or maximal amounts of tiles. There are certainly min-max strategies to getting high scores, but it's never interested me to take this game that seriously.[hr][/hr]The more connections you make successfully, the more tiles are added to the stack allowing you to build further. There are special tiles to unlock by hitting certain milestones or physically stretching your towns in one direction for a while, like a little scene of a deer in a clearing in a forest or a tugboat on a river.The vibes? Immaculate. Chill background music and adorable visuals give this game a really cozy charm. The game is exactly what it looks like, so you can easily tell if this game is for you or not.[hr][/hr]I love a game that has a clear vision for what it is and achieves on it. I wish more games were as well executed as this one is.

134780265.review:
Oof. I really wanted to love this game- the art is so pretty and cute, and the tile placement thing seemed like such a neat twist on city builders, which I *love*. Before We Leave had a similar hex-based aesthetic, which I thought worked really well.

However, the game is extremely rigid, lacking even the flexibility of solitaire: you can't reshuffle your tiles or use anything other than your top tile. And you can only place tiles directly adjacent to other tiles, making it basically impossible to plan routes for things like rivers and railroads.

Overall, while I liked the aesthetic, I realized after about an hour and a half it was tedious and frustrating more than fun and relaxing.

The music fits the vibe really well and the controls are easy enough to pick up, and I'd give it a pass for how the different land types do not blend well at all, but the gameplay just isn't enjoyable.

F+

134668403.review: This is a really fun, relaxing, and simple yet challenging game. The music is beautiful, the art style is pretty and cute, and it's a nice way to just chill out and grow a giant forest if you'd like, or challenge yourself with relatively simple puzzles. Although I am still working on two achievements, I am quite happy sometimes just watching my little boats swim around, or my trains chug along, or the little animals wander about. The sound design is lovely, and it's quite satisfying to hear the rotation and placement in this game. All around, this is a lovely game, perfect for folks who like puzzles. If you, like me, have no ability to design visual things, don't worry about it. Design nous not required. The creative mode is there if you'd like, but classic mode is purely puzzle and score-based, with lots of different ways to advance.

134610947.review:
Simple rules, cutely drawn bestagons, unobtrusive music. If you are looking for a truly relaxing game that is pleasant to look at here it is. 

Negative reviews usually give an example of Carcassonne board game reduced only to "world building" with cards. While true to a certain degree, it is not an issue as the game gets progressively more difficult and the game mechanics keep you on your toes the longer you play. In the later stages it require a definitive degree of focus and planning should you aim for a really long playthrough or are motivated to collect the in-game rewards = unique new tiles (which serve as the Steam achievements at the same time).

If you look for deep and complex game mechanics or any resemblance of action, give it a pass.
If you on the other hand look for a chill gameplay that can pose a moderate challenge should you stick with it longer, go for it.

133928512.review:
I call my wife the Dork Romantik every time she plays this 10/10 game

I love RTSs and city builders, I have since the early days of Sim City and Warcraft II. I always wanted that sort of gameplay, but without the upkeep/conflict.

This is a relaxing, soothing game.  It's not here to measure your epeen, it's not here to prove how much better you are than the computer/ai/opponent. This is a game to play when the day has been too much and you need to UNWIND.

Remember unwinding?  Remember playing games for fun instead of endless challenge? Remember games as an escape from the horrors of reality? Dorfromantik does.

The gameplay is very similar to a hexagonal Carcassonne, where the challenge is in the tile laying not the upkeep and maintenance, but without Carcassonne's ridiculous point counting system.

I think even full price is well worth the enjoyment you can get from this.

GREAT ON STEAMDECK

133767976.review:
This is a tile-placing game, not unlike Carcassonne, except that you're working with hexes rather than squares. Each quadrant of the hex can contain one of the following: meadow, forest, city, fields, water, or train track. Your goal is to place the tiles such that each biome forms continuous groups, which is both worth points and aesthetically pleasing. The tiles are weighted so that you don't usually end up with a chaotic mess on every tile; normally there'll be a "theme" to the tile - such as woodlands, which will generally have three or four of the corners filled with trees, maybe with some meadows or houses/city on the other sides. Water and train tracks are annoyances, since you can't mismatch tile borders like you can with anything else - if you want to cap off a train track, the tile you're placing must have a track ending on it; which makes it harder to complete perfect tiles around them.

You start off with 50ish tiles, and there's only two ways to earn more - completing missions, which requires you to expand one biome to either a minimum size, to an exact size, or to close out a zone so that it's fully enclosed by other biomes, each of which earns 5 tiles; or to place 'perfect' tiles - a tile that is surrounded on all sides by biomes that match that tile - which earns 1 new tile per perfect tile.

Anyway, the game is very relaxing with pleasant music and the graphics are beautiful. It's easy to pick up, but tough to reach ever higher high scores. There's a bunch of achievements, which unlock unique tiles or new map themes.

It's fun. I'm glad I picked it up.

132582958.review:
Review at Patch: "10th of February"
Hours Clocked: 6

Considering this is the second copy of Dorfromantik I own, I other being on the Nintendo Switch, I do recommend it.

The game is straightforward, you place hexagonal tiles adjacent to others, build a scene and continue going until you run out of tiles to put down. They can be rotated to match sides for bonuses. Simple enough, but the hook is keeping your pile of tiles flowing.

While you can simply go for making a pretty scene, there is something satisfying about using lots of tiles to make a large diorama of your own design. Getting more tiles through completion of challenges, and perfect matches does not impede the relaxing style either.

As you play, you will unlock new tiles like a Beaver Dam, or Old Tree that can crop up in you your tiles for more variety. On top of that, you will unlock new themes like Enchanted or Fjords which you can toggle for extra appeal or flavor. They can all be on at the same time too, so you can get a whole cornucopia of variety if you so choose.

When your game ends, you can continue it in Creative Mode if you really liked how it turned out, or you can start a again. You can also save your maps that you might have taken a liking to, so even if you can't add anything else to it, you can show it off or just admire the boats, trains and nature sounds.

Overall my recommendation of Dorfromantik is Recommended.

[h1]The Good[/h1]
[list]

132402158.review:
Anyone who has played the board game Carcassonne will immediately recognize Dorfromantik as being based on the same sort of domino-like idea, but Dorfromantik is still significantly different. The main thing is that it's a solitaire game. It's also a little more elaborate and challenging due to the hexagonal tile design, and the game rules are somewhat customizable.

I'm not really a big player of these types of games and mostly got it because my niece and nephew like this sort of game (it's good for younger kids) but even I still think it's pretty good for what it is. In addition to the standard , quick, and hard modes, there is also a custom mode and a monthly challenge mode. The custom modes have a seed which ensures the same sequence of tiles for anyone who uses the seed, thus multiple people can compete to see who can get the highest score with the same tile sequence and restrictions. There's also a "creative" mode that, while I wouldn't call it a "true" creative mode, lets you just freely place tiles and delete/discard them to see what sort of map you can draw.

The UI is also simple and well designed, so any kid old enough to use a mouse will probably be able to figure it out pretty much immediately.

And one of the best parts about this game is that at anytime you can simply put it own and walk away and return without having to spend any brain tax to figure out what you were doing when you last played. Other visual cues the devs finally did add - such as tile-edge match highlighting - are very difficult to see.

Overall, the game is fun and relaxing, unless you need to strain your eyes and/or can't constantly hold down the left-shift key for hours on end.

So thumbs-up for the great concept.
Thumbs-down for not even trying to accommodate accessibility needs after nearly two years of being live.

131813977.review:
This game highlights the problem with Steam's yes or no system.
The game is painfully repetitive, and within two hours you've pretty much seen and done all there is to it. Yes, you might unlock a new tile that serves no purpose at some future point, or even an equally purposeless different colour scheme, but you can't work towards it because you have no idea what specific action beyond "Complete a quest" will do so.
Dorfromantic is essentially 6-sided dominoes with pictures instead of dots. It's easy enough for a 5 year old to pick up in 5 minutes, but the tactics and concentration can take MUCH longer to master.
The game's repetition is its greatest flaw, but much as I found it unimaginative to play, there's something beautiful and mesmerising about it. The gentle music and the cute little landscapes had me thinking about the game FAR more than I actually played it. They combine to create something truly blissful. That said, the concentration and tactics required to master it are not at all relaxing - in fact, it's more like a stressful exam. The game depends upon what appears to be random tiles, but that randomness can also be your downfall where, no matter how flawlessly you play, you may simply never receive the tiles you need to attain the high scores or unlock more cards or specials.
I would give this a 7 out of 10 if Steam had scores, and it's great to see Toukana continuing to enhance it. I WOULD buy this again, especially at just £7.69, but it's all about the atmosphere, not the game play.

131801955.review:
Dorfromantik is the ultimate procrastination tool masquerading as a game. 
It's a digital version of adult coloring books, a puzzle on steroids, a black hole of tile-matching goodness that sucks you in and never lets you go.
A virtual puzzle but instead of just fitting them together, you get the satisfaction of creating a unique new world.
It's like meditation but with less incense and more pixels.
If you're looking for a stress-reliever, a  zone out or just something to kill time, give Dorfromantik a try. 
The only downside is that you might find yourself neglecting your responsibilities to play this game.
Just don't blame me when you realize you've spent the entire day trying to get perfect tiles instead of doing work.

131783699.review:
Such a simple concept.
Start with a number of 6 sided puzzle pieces and an empty board with 1 starting piece.
Place your puzzle piece one by one on the board connecting them.
Each side of the piece can be water, trees, house, railroad track, water, corn field.
You can connect trees and a house, but that is only when you have no other options.
Place them so ideal as possible and make the country you are creating as big as possible.
Some pieces have tasks attached, for example grow a town as big as 500 houses.
When you complete these tasks you receive extra pieces to place.
Go as far as possible until you have no more pieces to place.

Very addictive and perfect for spending some free time to fill.

131591778.review:
This is easily one of my new favorite puzzle games. The replayability is really good and the challenge/achievement system is staggered in a way that ensures you don't get them all right away. Unlocking certain achievement paths happens in game when you reach certain preplaced tiles and finish the quests they give you. 

If you focus on unlocking all of the quest paths, you could probably unlock them all in under twenty hours. I, however, didn't know this was how you gain access to them, so I've racked up over 60 and haven't unlocked them all. I'm fine with this, but want to reassure you that, if you don't want to play this many hours before completing the game, you may not need to.

Aside from the achievements, the things I enjoy most about this game are the visuals, the turn-based play style, and the random selection of tiles ensuring replayability. Each game progresses slightly differently and you can take your time thinking about the right move before making it. As you unlock new biomes/seasons/skins in the game, the color and style gradient between the tiles gets more and more complex, leaving you with a really pleasing rainbow of a landscape. It's very nice to look at.

If you like thoughtful puzzle games, this is a must-have!

131299261.review:
You ever played Carcassone, a boardgame about earning points by placing tiles? You know, you get a tile per turn, you gotta place it in ways that would help you secure more points. This is literally it but with hexagons and singleplayer, and more freeform - and because there's no other player competing for the meeple figurine placement, there's way more creativity involved to make a prettier landscape. Also, no meeple placement either.

This one can be both seriously challenging if you feel like going for high scores, and at same time super comforting, allowing you to create endearingly comforting rural landscapes with towns, railways and rivers. There's some unlocking to do trough achievements too, adding new visual bits, and those may take time but aren't that super tough to actually secure, since the game is really gripping so it's a matter of time till you unlock everything.

Of you enjoy relaxing tile placement at any capacity, go ahead, buy it!

There are the first 2-3 hours of the game which leans into the more relaxing and beautiful side of the game. After I did the first few ~15k runs, I felt like I was kinda done with it, but noticed I had like 10% achivement rate, so I checked them out.

130087596.review:
If you like a puzzle game which requires thinking, structure and order, then this is the game for you.
The concept is relatively simple, you put puzzle pieces together (grass / houses / water / rail / farmland / forest) and you score points for putting them in the correct spot.
 
It is one of those games that you'll either find relaxing and peaceful or you'll get frustrated by not having the puzzle pieces in place. You do a lot better when you take your time and in the right frame of mind. 

This is a game that only the Germans could develop. You'll understand why if you play it long enough.

Dorfromantik is a simple and yet addicting world builder that provides you with random puzzle pieces that you have to use to create a world however you must be smart with your placement as your next set of pieces relies on the utilisation of prior pieces

129972501.review:
Reminds me a lot of Mini Metro.  It's a relaxing, casual game that requires a bit of thinking and problem solving.  But with how simple / minimal the control are - you only have two things to be concerned with - where do I place the tile, and how do I rotate it.  I can really understand why this has been nominated for so many awards - rightfully so.
Graphics are great.
Controls are intuitive.
Rules are simple.
Music is pleasing.
